Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Continuous Femoral Nerve Block Duration After Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to continue ropivacaine or switch to normal saline.

Participants.evidence: patients undergoing tricompartment total knee arthroplasty

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to continue ropivacaine or switch to normal saline.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial evaluated whether extending a continuous femoral nerve block (cFNB) to 4 days postoperatively enhances recovery compared to an overnight cFNB in patients undergoing tricompartment total knee arthroplasty.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcomes were the time to achieve three discharge criteria (adequate analgesia, independence from intravenous analgesics, and ambulation of at least 30 m) and ambulatory distance in 6 minutes the afternoon after surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Twenty-five patients were randomised to each group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The 4-day ropivacaine group met discharge criteria in a median of 25 hours (25th–75th percentiles: 21–47) compared to 71 hours (46–89) in the control group (estimated ratio, 0.47; 95% CI, 0.32–0.67; P < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported, with no differences in frequency or severity between groups.
